Headline: Recovery eluding many big retailers

Headline: Some Companies Are Taking Longer to Pay Suppliers Despite Recovery; Macy's and Mondelez are among the businesses negotiating longer payment terms after getting used to them during the pandemic
Lead_Paragraphs: Last spring, when the coronavirus pandemic hit the U.S. economy, many companies asked their suppliers for more time to pay their bills. A year later, some of them are holding on to the better terms, freeing up extra cash.  Big U.S. companies on average took 58 days to pay suppliers in their first quarters of fiscal 2021, up 5.5% from 55 days in the comparable period last year, according to research from Hackett Group Inc. The business advisory firm gathered the data from corporate disclosures for 938 of the largest public U.S. companies by revenue that have reported results for their fiscal first quarter, excluding financial institutions.
